title: Before 31 December 2017, will President Trump sign legislation removing the ACA's individual mandate to purchase health insurance?
preds: Depends on the weather for golfing in Florida
Why hasn't this Q closed yet? Holidays?

The GOP Tax Bill Repeals Obamacare's Individual Mandate. Here's What That Means for You Mukherjee (2017) December 20, states that: The GOP’s new tax bill, which passed Congress on Wednesday afternoon after one last vote in the House of Representatives and will be signed by President Donald Trump, is also a health care bill. The tax bill does at least as much (if not more) to upend Obamacare, or the Affordable Care Act, than even all of the Trump administration’s thousand cuts to the health law over the past year by repealing the individual mandate. Which raises the question: Just what is the Obamacare individual mandate? And what does its repeal mean for Americans? For starters: Contrary to a statement that President Trump made Wednesday, nixing Obamacare’s individual mandate does not mean that Obamacare has been repealed in the GOP tax bill. The individual mandate, which requires most Americans (other than those who qualify for a hardship exemption) to carry a minimum level of health coverage, is actually still in effect for 2018—meaning that you may have to pay a steep tax fine if you don’t have health insurance, for one thing. And even after the individual mandate repeal goes into effect the following year, Obamacare’s individual insurance markets, federal subsidies to help Americans pay monthly insurance premiums, and Medicaid expansion in the dozens of states that implemented it will all still be in effect barring further Congressional action (para. 1-2). Mukherjee, S. (2017). The GOP Tax Bill Repeals Obamacare's Individual Mandate. Here's What That Means for You. Fortune. Politics. Retrieved from
http://fortune.com/2017/12/20/tax-bill-individual-mandate-obamacare/ Trump signs tax, government spending bills into law Heavey and Lambert (2017) December 22, states that: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump signed Republicans’ massive $1.5 trillion tax overhaul into law on Friday, cementing the biggest legislative victory of his first year in office, and also approved a short-term spending bill that averts a possible government shutdown. Trump said he wanted to sign the tax bill before leaving Washington on Friday for his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida, rather than stage a more formal ceremony in January, so he could keep his promise to finish work before Christmas. “I didn’t want you folks to say I wasn’t keeping my promise. I‘m keeping my promise,” he told reporters in the White House. The two pieces of legislation represent Trump’s most significant accomplishment with Congress since taking office in January, as well as a sign of what awaits when he returns from Florida after the Christmas holiday (para. 1-4). Heavey, S. & Lambert, L. (2017). Trump signs tax, government spending bills into law. Reuters. Politics. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax/trump-signs-tax-government-spending-bills-into-law-idUSKBN1EG1T1

The Senate voted to waive the automatic cuts 91-8 on Thursday. So I believe DT will sign ASAP

The House has passed, as part of the government funding bill,  a waiver of the automatic cuts - which would allow signing of the tax bill before end-2017. However, the Senate may (or may not) strip this measure from their version  - it requires 60 votes. Some Republicans, like Rand Paul, are not in favor either. One difficulty of stripping the waiver is that the House would have to vote again on the amended bill - which would be difficult as they are reportedly leaving town now - so the Dems in the Senate may decide to acquiesce to the House version, not to be blamed for a government shutdown. See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-21/house-approves-temporary-funding-to-avert-government-shutdown

Updating my previous forecast (again) due to the fact that the House just passed legislation to keep the government funded. It seems highly likely that the Senate will pass it today, too. This should clear the way for the tax bill to be passed before the end of the year.

Swinging back to 0 as it is doubtful that Senate Dems will agree to the PAYGO waiver which means it is unlikely to be included in the continuing resolution on the budget. Apparently, nearly the entire House Democratic caucus last week threatened to block a PAYGO waiver unless Republicans made concessions like restoring the Obamacare individual mandate.

The GOP finally killed the ACA's individual mandate WASHINGTON -- The House passed a tax reform bill Tuesday, which includes a repeal of the Affordable Care Act's individual insurance mandate, by a vote of 227-203 -- but an issue that came up in the Senate means the House will have to vote yet again, most likely on Wednesday.
After the House voted on the bill, the Senate parliamentarian ruled that certain provisions in it violate Senate rules and will have to be changed. After the Senate passes the revised bill (expected to happen late Tuesday or early Wednesday), it will have to go back to the House for a re-vote and then on to President Trump for his signature.
_________________________
COMMENTS: I'm sure DT is eager to sign this; time is short now, it depends if he prefers to be in Florida golfing instead.

https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/21/house-unveils-bill-to-fund-the-government-through-jan-point-19.html Republicans are now trying to put the paygo waiver into the Continuing resolution today. "Buried on the last page is what's called a "pay-go" waiver: language that would allow President Donald Trump to immediately sign the tax bill Republicans' passed Thursday without running afoul of rules that prohibit the government from enacting big new expenditures, such as the GOP tax cuts, unless there is money in the current year's budget to pay for them. Without such a waiver, Trump will likely have to wait two more weeks and sign the tax bill in January, when Republicans would have another 12 months to figure out how to make the expensive tax cuts conform to pay-go rules. It remained unclear Thursday how exactly Ryan intended to pass the CR in the House — whether by Republican votes only or with support from Democrats. It was likewise unclear exactly what the Senate would do if the House passes the measure — offer a separate spending package or just vote to send the House CR to Trump's desk before midnight on Friday. The House is expected to adjourn for the holidays following Thursday's votes."
Oh, how at the sky I guess, he wants to kick off the new year with a signing...

So, I have to go to zero now. #1) - Trump celebrated victory today already..Trump, who praised the Republican bill as a "historic victory for the American people" at a Cabinet meeting Wednesday, is holding an event at the White House in the afternoon with GOP members of the House and Senate to celebrate passage,

Looks like Trump will sign on Jan 3, as others have said, unless an unlikely last-minute fix is agreed with the Democrats by Friday (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-20/trump-is-said-to-plan-tax-signing-jan-3-due-to-technical-issue)

I am lowering my forecast once again, this time to 15 percent. Under a 2010 "pay-as-you-go" law, Congress has to offset any new spending or lower taxes with automatic cuts to Medicare and other programs. This law would create across-the-board spending cuts that the GOP would most likely not want to take responsibility for. In order to pay the tax bill without the spending cuts, Congress must pass a waiver that is not filibuster-proof. If President Trump waits until 2018 to pass the tax bill, Congress will have a full year to pass the waiver. At the moment, this seems like a much more likely possibility than trying to rush the passing the waiver before the end of the year.
Downgrading my previous forecast to 50 percent based on reports that the bill may not signed until January 2018. Whether the bill is signed in 2017 or 2018 appears to be a toss up at this point.

Downgrading my estimate based on new report from Rep. McCarthy. Apparently Trump may delay signature on tax overhaul bill (with repeal of ACA mandate) per request from businesses, who are required to re-calculate the impact of new laws on their balance sheets in the quarter that the President signs the bill into law. I doubt Trump wants to be known as the President who ruined Christmas for CEOs, CFOs and CPA's. https://www.wsj.com/livecoverage/tax-bill-2017
News story as of 12/20 that Trump may not sign tax bill until January
The Republicans Tax Bill will contain elimination of the INDIVIDUAL MANDATE I believe.

A repeal of the individual mandate is a part of the tax bill that passed the House earlier today and is expected to pass the Senate later this evening. Most reports suggest that the Senate will pass this bill this evening and that President Trump will most likely sign it before Christmas. That said, I think it's a near certainty that President Trump will sign legislation removing the individual mandate and it's highly likely that he will do so before the end of the year.

Repeal of the individual mandate remains in the proposed tax bill. The GOP apparently has enough Senate votes to pass it without having to rely on Sen. McCain, who is now home after treatment for his brain tumor. Sen. Collins, Corker, and Rubio have retracted their objections. The remaining question is when the vote will be scheduled. If it is not scheduled before 12/21, the chances of it passing fall drastically due to impending spending bill deadline. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/17/us/politics/john-mccain-cancer-tax-bill.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fpolitics

Barring a sudden outbreak of political courage--or failing that, political common sense--in the Senate, this is scheduled to pass next week, probably Tuesday. As a result, the Republicans will lose the Senate and maybe even the House as well as large numbers of seats in various state legislatures, some of which will be surprising.   In the meantime, large numbers of his supporters will lose their health insurance and their jobs to the increasingly uncaring wealthy, and their lives and their children's to the increasingly available opioids. Attached to tax bill will pass.
The votes are in... The Senate will vote next week.

Increased my prediction slightly based on a few events that passed. However, the following challenges remain.
(1) Presenting a joint Senate/House tax bill that needs to address. These are sizeable issues with vested special interests that will take some negotiating (examples include Sen. Rubio & the children tax credit, Delta airline's effort to tax foreign airlines) [85% chance of success] 
(2) Preventing deficit hawks from defecting due to the projected $1-1.5 trillion deficit [95% chance of success]  Republicans are keen to pass this tax bill to appease big donors and powerful lobbying groups despite its global unpopularity with voters. This may give a few senators pause. Because the GOP has decided to pursue this via Budget Reconciliation, passage now depends on 2-3 keys senators vs. 10+ via the traditional route, giving holdouts an enormous amount of leverage. If enough GOP senators begin asking for special clauses (e.g. Rubio), this could delay bicarmeral passage of the bill by >1 week, thereby subjecting it to the following:
(3) Avoiding a government shutdown by passing a 2 week temporary spending patch this week due by 12/09 - done
(4) Avoiding a government shutdown by passing a spending bill by 12/22 (needs 60 Senate votes) [75% chance of success] 
(5) Resolving DACA, which Democrats and a few Republicans favor before #4 is done [70% chance of success] 
(6) Finally, all of this happening before 12/31 [60%] Thus, my adjusted prediction is now 35%.

As of 12/13/017 removal of mandate is part of the tax bill. Rubio is currently apposed to tax bill so small chance that it won't pass. Tax bill is mostly finalized so little chance of passing without removing the mandate

Nobody should be surprised at this, since it is precisely what he said (albeit in other words) he would pursue if elected. Repeal is in the conference committee bill. Rubio can be ignored unless Collins becomes a No but he's more likely to be appeased. Jones will be sworn in later so Corker and one more Senator can be lost.

New Alabama Senator Doug Jones will not be seated until at least January. This question specifies that the President must sign the individual mandate repeal before 31 December 2017. Senate Republicans now have increased incentive to resolve their new tax plan and associated individual mandate repeal this year before their 52 seat majority is reduced to 51 when Jones takes office. Therefore, the recent election of Jones actually increases the odds that this legislation will be signed in 2017. There is plenty of reason to believe that the individual mandate will still be in place on January 1, 2018, but don't be fooled into thinking that the election of Jones makes that scenario more likely.
Two names: Susan Collins and Doug Jones.

I had thought the Republican effort to repeat the ACA had been resolved earlier. However, the Senate version of the tax bill includes a provision to remove the individual mandate. However, despite controlling both the House and Senate, this does not mean that the individual mandate will be removed by 12/31/17. Senate/House conference committee still needs to reconcile both versions of the bill. At issue remains:
(1) Presenting a joint Senate/House tax bill that needs to address: the individual mandate (probably yes), SALT deduction (McConnell now wants to increase), medical expense deductions (lower threshold), mortgage deduction (key for GOP blue state reps), resolve number of individual tax brackets (5 vs. 7), estate tax,  corporate tax rate (20 vs. 22%), corporate AMT (effect on R&D), Johnson amendment (churches can lobby), teacher/student deductions.
These are sizeable issues with vested special interests that will take some negotiating [85% chance of success]
(2) Preventing deficit hawks from defecting due to the projected $1-1.5 trillion deficit [95% chance of success]
(3) Avoiding a government shutdown by passing a 2 week temporary spending patch this week due by 12/09 [90% chance of success]
(4) If #3 is passed, avoiding a government shutdown by passing a spending bill by 12/22 (needs 60 Senate votes) [75% chance of success]
(5) Resolving DACA, which Democrats and a few Republicans favor before #4 is done [70% chance of success]
(6) Finally, all of this happening before 12/31 [60%] Thus, my final prediction is 23%. But if the spending patch or spending bill fail to pass and the government is shut down, this chance drops significantly. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/06/business/house-senate-tax-bill-differences.html?_r=0
https://www.wsj.com/articles/republican-leaders-push-spending-patch-to-avoid-shutdown-1512341550
https://www.wsj.com/articles/dreamers-fate-hangs-over-efforts-to-avert-government-shutdown-1512642601

House and Senate negotiators thrashing out differences over a major tax bill are likely to eliminate the insurance coverage mandate at the heart of the Affordable Care Act, lawmakers say. But a deal struck by Senate Republican leaders and Senator Susan Collins of Maine to mitigate the effect of the repeal has been all but rejected by House Republicans, potentially jeopardizing Ms. Collins’s final yes vote.

Some news made me reconsider the odds. There is intense lobby and push back from Corporations (and Chamber of Commerce) against the retention of the AMT. The AMT retains about 40 billions, chump change for a 1.5 trillion tax bill, but the Senate must follow some rules (to avoid filibuster),  Since this is more a corporate tax reform than anything else, the outcries would push the House to go to Conference, instead of just voting to pass the Senate bill. 
Second piece of info, it looks like they really want to do this before the end of the year, so I'll increase the odd it will pass before the end of the year.  1. Avoid conference, Houses pass Senate Bill (which has the repeal language) [20% chance] AND 
done it before the end of the year [80% chance since there is plenty of time and only involve the House] AND 
President Trump has no objection [100%, he already voiced his support, as is] AND 
President Trump signs it [98% ... well the question asks "... will President Trump..." so I presume President Pence wouldn't count if Trump has a heart attack or assassinated or whatever other calamity that the Democrats are wishing to Trump] OR 
2. (a) House chose to go to conference [80%] 
(b) The repeal language survive conference and shows up in the consolidated bill [100%] AND 
(c) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill [80%] AND 
(d) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill before then end of the year [70%] AND 
(e) President Trump doesn't object to the final bill [95%, there could be chances something new creeps up into the final bill that Trump doesn't like and don't underestimate the Republicans' ability to fumble] AND 
(f) Trump physically signs it [98%] This resolves to (15.7% + 41.7%) = 57.4% YES. (I misread the question, it clearly said that taking away the penalty resolves to a yes)

Too many lobbyists have to be pacified first, and they all rank ahead of President Littlefingers in the minds of the Congressional leadership just now. I still think they'll strip out the insurance mandate before it goes up to the White House, but I have been pretty consistently in the range of Not So Good to Egregiously Wrong in the past few months.  I think I calibrated my education wrong--spent too much time studying politics and economics and policy and stuff like that and not nearly enough time watching Saturday morning cartoons, which would have given me a firmer grip on what now passes for reality.

Increases the odd for it to have president signature by Christmas. 
(1) The three Senators who opposed the ACA repeal is now on board and voted for the repeal of the individual mandate in the tax bill:
"The surprising about-face in the past two days by Sens. John McCain of Arizona, Alaska's Lisa Murkowski and, finally on Friday, Susan Collins of Maine guarantees that GOP leaders in the Senate will win passage of their major tax legislation." Source CNBC
https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/01/senators-who-saved-obamacare-support-bill-that-would-hurt-obamacare.html (2) The Republicans reasoned that (a) the Supreme Court, in a Justice Roberts majority opinion, stated that the individual mandate of the ACA is upheld because it is a tax; (b) that it is a tax on the lower middle class, since the upper middle class and the rich can afford it or have jobs that has health insurance benefits and the poor has medicaid; and (c) the repeal of the mandate saves $340 billions over 10 years. Put aside partisan critics, right or wrong, these are the reasons that it was included unopposed by the Republicans (Democrats opposed it) into the tax bill. Since we are dealing with a Republic majority Congress, in order to predict the outcome, what the Senators can justify in their heads carry more weight than what the opposition party says. "The mandate's revocation was added to the bill because it would free up nearly $340 billion in extra federal funds during the next decade, which could be used to provide bigger tax breaks in the legislation. The savings would result from the federal government not having to subsidize as many Obamacare private insurance plans as it does now." Source CNBC sited above. And (3) there is hint today that the House will pass the Senate version as-is to avoid conference altogether. This would speed up the bill to the President's desk. The Senate version is very close to the House's version:
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/02/us/politics/republicans-tax-cuts.html I am upping the odds to 58% from 35% for the above reason. Why not 100%? In order to resolve the question to a Yes, the following must be true (and the odd it of each outcome):
1. Avoid conference, Houses pass Senate Bill (which as the repeal language) [50% chance] AND
    done it before the end of the year [80% chance since there is plenty of time and only involve the House] AND
    President Trump has no objection [100%, he already voiced his support, as is] AND
    President Trump signs it [98% ... well the question asks "... will President Trump..." so I presume President Pence wouldn't count if Trump has a heart attack or assassinated or whatever other calamity that the Democrats are wishing to Trump]  OR
 2. (a) House chose to go to conference [50%]
      (b) The repeal language survive conference and shows up in the consolidated bill [100%] AND
     (c) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill [80%] AND
     (d) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill before then end of the year [50%] AND
     (e) President Trump doesn't object to the final bill [95%, there could be chances something new creeps up into the final bill that Trump doesn't like and don't underestimate the Republicans' ability to fumble] AND
     (f) Trump physically signs it [98%] This resolves to 39.2% + 18.6% = 57.8% YES.
Susan Collins showed that a repeal (and not replace) is acceptable provided greater medical expense deduction in tax bill.

Holding fast. Conference can present significant challenges. The CR situation is very much up in the air, with talk about passing a separate Defense appropriation and CR'ing the rest of the gov't (which still requires a bipartisan raising of the sequestration caps).  I concede the point made by @JMR2017 and others that the GOP is running scared and wants to pass something. The problem with running scared is it will be easier to strip out contentious items for the sake of expediency, since the tax debate is literally just a discussion of tax cuts for corporations and the rich. Leaving the individual mandate on the cutting room floor is arguably significantly easier than trying to shoehorn it in, no matter the estimated value.

House version doesn't have the repeal of individual mandate language, but Senate version has it. Since the CBO said it will save 350 billions to repeal the mandate, it will likely stay. The Senate killed earlier effort to to repeal ACA on its own, but this time, 51 of them signed up. 
Two reason why I didn't give this answer a 100% Yes: (1) the phrase "Before Dec 31, 2017", and (2) Republicans have mastered the art of fumbling. A prediction above concensus would be enough to hedge it.

Ryan supports repealing the mandate, a feature of the Senate tax cut bill. My feeling -- that's all, just a feeling -- is that the reconciliation process will either include the mandate repeal, or else the tax bill will fail to pass this year, if ever. Republicans are terrified of angry giant donors who have been withholding donations, demanding giant tax breaks or else. Democrats are terrified of their donors, for example the real estate industry, health care, state and local governments, etc. who will be hammered by this bill, whatever it is. This bill features approximately 500 pages with cross outs and extensive revisions hand written on the margins mean that nobody right now knows what they really voted for or against. No hearing ever were held of this last minute version of the bill. This is unprecedented in modern history, perhaps forever in the U.S.  How about voters? Many of the people hurt by this bill won't see its personal impact until they file their taxes in April 2019, after the midterm elections. Only if their Federal taxes being withheld from paychecks changes will they know. However, there is a significant amount of leeway in how employees and employers agree to withhold taxes. So I'm expecting that many middle class taxpayers will get a giant surprise come tax preparation time, but too late to vote their pain in the midterm elections. The Senate version of the tax bill satisfies a "yes" on this question. I still think that either they will drop it to get all Republican senators on board, or the signing will be delayed beyond end-2017. But given that (i) the provision generates over $300 billion in "savings", which will have to be made up elsewhere if it's dropped, and (ii) the big push to have the tax bill done before end-2017, there is a non-zero probability that this may be a "yes".

In case you missed the news, the Senate Parliamentarian ruled that reconciliation procedures can only be used until the end of the fiscal year (30 Sep). Which means, and Graham-Cassidy reconciliation bill would have to pass in both chambers in the next 6 joint legislative days (https://www.senate.gov/legislative/resources/pdf/2017_calendar.pdf - Senate has 11 days; https://www.majorityleader.gov/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/2017_ANNUAL_CALENDAR.pdf - House has  6 days). According to WaPo, "But the two senators have yet to unveil their bill, and it would have to undergo a Congressional Budget Office analysis before coming to the floor for a vote. To pass it by a simple majority in the Senate, that vote would have to take place before the current budget resolution expires at the end of the month." (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/the-health-202/2017/09/08/the-health-202-governors-want-obamacare-fixes/59b18d5e30fb04264c2a1d3d/) Unless Congress can somehow figure out how to pass a budget before the end of the FY (which they won't, since they agreed to a CR until December 8), they'll likely not be able to use reconciliation in the coming months. They could pass a budget authorizing reconciliation procedures for ACA, but given Congress's history of bumping up against deadlines, and looking at the same calendars above, Congress would have 4 joint legislative days to pass this legislation and get it in front of POTUS. Not to mention, it will have to contend with tax reform, which will use the same reconciliation procedures, and both pieces of legislation are prohibited from being considered simultaneously using reconciliation. So, the GOP would have to prioritize revisiting the health care fight over tax reform before the end of the calendar year, all while having to pass a budget.

Skinny repeal failure tilts this heavily toward zero; however, the house bill made it out of the house, suggesting a vague consensus around a repeal-replace plan that can be acceptable to Republicans and that features removal of individual mandate.  With this in mind, the failure margin in the Senate is small - the skinny repeal failed 51-49, so only one senator needs to flip to bring in Mike Pence for a tie-breaker - I suspect McCain is the most likely candidate to flip. Nevertheless, McConnell has announced his intention to move past healthcare for this session of Congress.  Although President Trump continues to push and tweet about proceeding on healthcare, his administration recently experienced a divergence from the Republican establishment (resignation of Reince Priebus); this shift eliminates a key avenue for his pressure to actually bear fruit. As a result, Republican legislators face the same usual pressure they have since the 2010 midterms, namely their base wants to see something happen; they also face pressure from the optics of being totally in control of the government and yet failing to make a successful run at their signature issue of the last 7 years; and, as noted, they face pressure from the de facto leader of their party (POTUS).  In aggregate, there is still some chance legislation would be passed.

The individual mandate would not be very costly to offset with increased taxes or taxes from other sources.  Some sort of compromise with Democrats may yet be possible during tax reform or budget negotiations.  This would give Republicans some small measure of vindication after 7 years of promises.

http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/19/mccain-diagnosed-with-brain-tumor-240739
Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) has been diagnosed with a brain tumor following an operation to remove a blood clot above his left eye.
McCain and his family are considering options for treating the tumor, including radiation and chemotherapy. The 80-year-old McCain has previously successfully been treated for skin cancer. “The Senator and his family are reviewing further treatment options with his Mayo Clinic care team. Treatment options may include a combination of chemotherapy and radiation," said a statement from the Mayo Clinic in Phoenix. “The Senator’s doctors say he is recovering from his surgery ‘amazingly well’ and his underlying health is excellent.” A statement from McCain's office said the veteran lawmaker is "in good spirits as he continues to recover at home with his family in Arizona. He is grateful to the doctors and staff at Mayo Clinic for their outstanding care, and is confident that any future treatment will be effective." There is no word on if, or when, McCain will return to the Senate. His absence from Capitol Hill — while less important than McCain's health — does leave Republicans short a reliable vote as they try to take on health care and other contentious issues. According to the statement from the Mayo Clinic, McCain has a type of brain tumor called a glioblastoma. The American Brain Tumor Association says such tumors are "usually highly malignant," spread rapidly and are difficult to treat. McCain called Sen. Jeff Flake, his fellow Arizona Republican, to tell him the news, Flake said on Twitter. "Tough diagnosis, but an even tougher man."

As noted by @JMR2017 and reported by various outlets (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/amid-uncertainty-about-mccains-health-senate-returns-with-gop-agenda-in-flux/2017/07/17/6dd31530-6b02-11e7-9c15-177740635e83_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_mccain-210pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.b465b0d1aa2f), Sens. Lee and Moran have come out against BCRA. With three weeks in session, this is a major blow to the GOP effort to repeal the ACA. While it's possible the GOP can revise the bill sufficiently enough in the next week or so to gain full GOP support and push through the Senate for further fast tracking in the House (as I discussed in an earlier post: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/537012), it's unlikely this will be the case.  Reconciliation procedures expire at the end of the FY, and with a budget resolution and debt ceiling raise still pending, the GOP is unlikely to complete this under FY17 reconciliation. Pursuing during FY18 is possible, although it would delay tax reform, but would likely fall outside the window of this question.  With that said, I'm significantly lowering, but not yet writing off, the possibility of legislation reaching Trump's desk by the end of the CY. I thought the health care fight was over after the failed attempt in March, but was surprised when the House was able to turn it around and pass it a few weeks later. So I'll be cautious (perhaps overly so), and wait to see how the GOP comes back from this in the next few weeks.  The silver lining is that this probably clears the table for Wray to be confirmed as the new FBI director, helping a different question to forecast on.

Senators Jerry Moran and Mike Lee have come out indicating that they will not support even a motion to proceed with the vote to repeal Obamacare. Therefore, McCain's absence doesn't matter. https://twitter.com/search?q=jerry+moran+and+mike+lee&ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Esearch

He has to. The individual mandate is the defining characteristic of Obamacare, with its fines for those who go without, and because of this will score the biggest political windfall. Republicans have to have legislative victories going into next year--this is especially true for the individual representatives and senators, as they need something to highlight.

Slight increase back to my starting point based on House member comments that the Senate bill, if left as is, will likely pass a floor vote in the House without changes (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/if--if--the-senate-passes-a-health-bill-get-ready-for-lightning-round-in-the-house/2017/07/15/522c8d08-68d1-11e7-a1d7-9a32c91c6f40_story.html?wpmm=1&wpisrc=nl_daily202). This signals that the GOP understands the challenges of getting the BCRA passed before the end of the FY (and their ability to use reconciliation until an FY18 budget resolution is passed), and that they will put aside factional differences to carry out a promise to constituents that's been 7 years in the making.  As much as the House may be trying to grease the skids to get this through, the major hurdle remains getting 51 votes in the Senate (50 senators and VP works for them). Based on the WaPo whip count (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2017/politics/ahca-senate-whip-count/?utm_term=.8819ec8bad1e&tid=a_inl) and other reporting, Collins and Paul are both No's (and unlikely to be persuaded to support the bill). Of those with "concerns," Capito, Heller, and Murkowski are the ones to watch (in my opinion). Alaska will get additional funds based on the latest revision (to woe Murkowski), and GOP leadership on Capito might bring her around to support the bill. Heller is in a tough spot, as supporting the bill will break with Sandoval, the Rep Governor, in a state that expanded Medicaid now under threat. Apparently Sandoval remains a hard No after this weekend's National Governor's Association (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/on-health-care-nevada-gov-brian-sandoval-isnt-buying-what-the-white-house-is-selling/2017/07/15/508b7270-6962-11e7-9928-22d00a47778f_story.html?utm_term=.a108cb1d4414&tid=a_inl), which increases the likelihood that Heller will oppose the bill in its current form.  Additionally, the CBO score of the Cruz amendment may make the BCRA even more toxic for vulnerable R's seeking reelection in 2018, giving them the political cover needed to oppose the bill.

The Trump/McConnellCare plan is on life support right now with diminishing chances of a Senate version. With 2 Republicans strongly opposed to the bill (Sen. Collins, & Paul) and Sen. McCain recovering from a craniotomy due intracranial bleeding, the Senatorial procedural vote to proceed with debate will not take place for several weeks. Even if/when debate is permitted, if the bill continues to cut Medicaid funding several moderate Republicans (Sen. Heller, Murkowski, McCain) will likely vote against it. And this is even before factoring in debate on the effects of the potentially more harmful Cruz amendment. Despite Sen. McConnell's claims, Americans did not vote for Trump to remake healthcare. They voted for him to "make America great again". For most supporters, that means jobs, incomes, and opportunity, not healthcare. Taking away healthcare is only slightly less popular than eliminating Social Security. Republicans underestimated the unpopularity and difficulty of repealing the ACA. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/16/us/politics/health-care-vote-john-mccain.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2017/politics/ahca-senate-whip-count/?utm_term=.d98065f0201a
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Slight downgrade for the delay in the vote (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/07/15/with-sen-mccain-out-for-eye-surgery-vote-on-health-care-bill-uncertain/?hpid=hp_rhp-top-table-main_mccain919pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.815ece191822). The longer it takes to get to a vote, the less likely it becomes for them to pass it during FY17 using reconciliation. Assuming McCain recovers quickly, the Senate will have 3 weeks left in session after next week.   Beyond the procedural challenges, there's significant concern among 11 R's, and 2 more have come out against the bill (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2017/politics/ahca-senate-whip-count/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_healthcare-whipcount%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.4d3757a124e9&wpisrc=nl_health202&wpmm=1). For the 11 with concerns, Republican governors may hold the key to how the senators from their states vote (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/on-health-care-nevada-gov-brian-sandoval-isnt-buying-what-the-white-house-is-selling/2017/07/15/508b7270-6962-11e7-9928-22d00a47778f_story.html?hpid=hp_rhp-top-table-main_healthbill501pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.80c64ba69fbb).  The CBO score, which should come out early next week, will provide a better indication of how this fight will shape up in the coming weeks. A particular item to pay attention to is whether the CBO scores the "Cruz amendment," as the score for the amendment may be a death blow to the bill for moderate R's (some have said they'll vote for the bill so long as the Cruz amendment is NOT scored).  Beyond the Senate drama, timing also becomes an issue, as the House (as of now) plans to keep it's recess as scheduled (at the end of July). If that remains the case, and given the budget challenges the House is currently facing (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/the-other-gop-stalemate-on-capitol-hill-house-budget-gridlock-imperils-tax-reform/2017/06/30/2d172304-5dc6-11e7-9b7d-14576dc0f39d_story.html?utm_term=.a7dab75c7d29), it seems it will be a challenge for the House and Senate to come to consensus on a specific bill prior to the end of the FY while also passing a budget. Admittedly, a CR is easier, but if a budget resolution isn't passed, the GOP cannot tackle tax reform and finish health care as the budget resolution is what enables reconciliation. And given the debt ceiling issue that will come to a head in October, the longer this takes for the GOP, the less likely it will happen. So my forecast is high as of now, given that the GOP is actually fairly close to achieving their goal by passing this bill. However, delays and further challenges to come to consensus makes it more likely that the GOP will snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.

http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/15/mcconnell-senate-to-defer-obamacare-repeal-vote-240596
The Senate will "defer" consideration of its attempt to repeal and replace Obamacare, said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Saturday night. The announcement follows Sen. John McCain's surgery that will keep him away from Washington next week. The bill has two GOP senators in opposition already and likely would have failed to advance with McCain's absence.

http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/lawmaker-news/341826-free-kevin-hassett-trumps-pick-a-victim-of-democratic
------------------------
"Once a given piece of legislation attracts bipartisan support, moderate Senate Republicans, who may otherwise waiver in their support, will find they can support the measure without the electoral risk that accompanies a strictly partisan measure. Political scientists call that “protecting one’s backside.
Indeed, in a Senate with only 52 Republican members, 60 votes may be easier to achieve than 51.” Comments: 
Repeal of the mandate has failed - - time to move to a market fix Options have narrowed, as Republicans can't solve the Rubrik's cube described by McConnell. He will keep acting tough in order to convince the President and "Freedom Committee" Senators (House is another matter) that maybe repeal/replace can happen but he likely believes that it can't. 2 Budget Reconciliation bills
What McConnell (corporations and the vast majority of Americans) really wants is to move on to tax reform.  According to the Budget Reconciliation rules, they may have to abandon the first bill (incorporating healthcare repeal) in order to move on to the second Budget Reconciliation vehicle intended for tax reform. (There is probably a loophole here but it may not be politically expedient).  It appears to me that Senate Mods have the upper hand with some unlikely allies like Senator Rand Paul. Susan Collins has been steadfast as well as Rand Paul – albeit for opposite reasons. And there are many followers and grandstanders who wait to see which way it’s going but really don’t want to destroy Medicaid or its expansion.  Republican Senator Susan Collins has been calling for Democrats to be involved in the healthcare debate but has been ignored so far. McConnell did indicate that an insurance market fix may need to happen if repeal/replace fails. This would require Dems because it would be outside the Reconciliation process open to filibuster. The Senate moderates understand Medicaid (covering seniors and people with disabilities in nursing homes who spent everything they had before death) as well as the Medicaid expansion that now just can’t be taken away—a big problem in red states. The bottom line is that there is no repeal/replace bill that can pass the Senate. I'm betting that Moderate R's rule because they are clear that Obamacare repeal is a loser for the 2018 election.  They need at least 8 Dems to cover their backsides so if they abandon repeal and go with a market fix they will get those votes and be able to move past the misery of health care and attempt to be champions of tax reform.

As with all the legislation questions, there's a lot of moving parts. As of this morning, BCRA (the GOP health care bill in the Senate) doesn't have the requisite votes to pass. Additionally, CBO's scoring of the BCRA should come Monday, which will give a better idea of whether the holdout R's might come around to supporting or if BCRA becomes even more toxic. There's still a month left for the Senate to pass this legislation with McConnell delaying the August recess, so there's still time for them to get something passed. Assuming the GOP can't get health care passed through the Senate, they might leave it alone until after they work through tax reform, knowing that it will be significantly harder to come to consensus, but with much stronger GOP support for revamping the tax plan. That would likely be the first bill they work on during FY18 using reconciliation (of which only one reconciliation bill can be in chamber at a time). However, if the GOP decides they need to pass health care reform, as it is a key assumption of revamping the tax code, there's a decent chance the House and Senate R's will be able to find some consensus and getting some form of legislation passed. One would assume it would repeal the individual mandate, but it might not. If the GOP can get BCRA through the Senate, there's still a chance they don't pass it during FY17, as the House and Senate would have to reconcile their versions of health care and pass the same bill in both chambers. With the budget and debt ceiling issues already taking up most of the schedule in September, the GOP might focus on getting the budget resolution in place, allowing them to use reconciliation for repealing ACA again in FY18 and continuing where they left off. That situation would significantly condense the schedule for passing legislation by the timeline above, but would give the GOP all of FY18 to work health care and tax reform. Hesitantly placing it at 55% for the time being, as the GOP has made progress on health care reform. The next couple weeks will provide the indicators as to whether this happens in FY17 using reconciliation procedures. The whip count this morning indicates there are 2 No's, and 8 "have concerns" (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2017/politics/ahca-senate-whip-count/?utm_term=.cfb1a2a6ab16). If McConnell can assuage those 8, this becomes much more likely.
